data.title: Syllabus to Weekly Planner
data.one_liner: A lightweight web app that converts course syllabi into personalized weekly study plans and tracks progress offline.
target_users: Students who want structured weekly study plans
assumptions: Users have access to course syllabi in digital format (text or PDF) and can input or paste key dates and topics
Users want a simple, repeatable weekly plan with daily tasks aligned to deadlines and topics
No backend is required for MVP; all data can be stored in the browser (localStorage) or in-memory
Users will interact with a basic calendar-like weekly view and progress indicators
There is no requirement for authentication in the MVP
Syllabi can be parsed or manually mapped to weeks by the user in a lightweight way
success_metrics: Demoable MVP achieves participation from at least 3 independent user tests or pilot users within 2 weeks
Average time to generate a weekly plan from a syllabus is under 5 minutes
At least 70% of planned weekly tasks are marked as completed after 2 weeks
User satisfaction score of 4/5 in feedback sessions
No external dependencies or backend services required for MVP

prd.title: Syllabus to Weekly Planner
prd.problem: College students often struggle to translate diverse course syllabi into actionable, weekly study plans. MVP constraints (offline usage, no backend, and no authentication) require a lightweight, browser-based solution that can convert syllabus content into a repeatable weekly plan while tracking progress locally.
target_users: Students who want structured weekly study plans
goals: Convert course syllabi into structured weekly study plans with tasks aligned to topics and deadlines
Support offline operation by storing all data in the browser (localStorage) without a backend
Provide both automatic syllabus-to-week mapping and lightweight manual mapping when automatic parsing is insufficient
Offer a calendar-like weekly view with progress indicators to track completion
Deliver a demoable MVP within 2 weeks with no external integrations
non_goals: Backend services, authentication, or user accounts
External integrations (calendars, to-do apps, or cloud storage) in MVP
Advanced natural language processing or full PDF parsing beyond lightweight mapping
Cross-device data sync or multi-user collaboration
Mobile-first native app implementation (web app only for MVP)
user_stories: As a student, I want to paste or type a syllabus into the app and automatically generate a week-by-week plan so I can start planning quickly.
As a student, I want to manually map syllabus topics to weeks when automatic parsing isn't possible, so I can still create a usable plan.
As a student, I want a calendar-like weekly view showing days and assigned tasks, so I can see my workload at a glance.
As a student, I want to add, edit, delete, and reorder daily tasks within each week, so I can customize my plan.
As a student, I want to mark tasks as completed and see progress indicators, so I can track my study progress.
As a student, I want all data to be stored locally in the browser so I can use the app offline and without an account.
As a student, I want to reset or clear data, so I can start fresh for a new syllabus.
As a student, I want a simple progress dashboard showing completed vs planned tasks and weekly completion trends, so I can monitor my performance.
functional_requirements: Provide a text input area where users can paste or type syllabus content (text or lightweight structured data) and optionally specify key dates and topics
Support automatic mapping of syllabus content to weeks when structured markers are detected, and a lightweight manual mapping UI when automatic mapping is insufficient
Generate a weekly plan with weeks and days, displaying tasks aligned to topics and deadlines derived from the mapping
Allow CRUD operations on tasks (create, edit, delete) and reordering within each day
Enable marking of tasks as completed and compute per-week and overall progress percentages
Persist all project data in browser localStorage with a simple versioned schema and graceful handling of storage limits or resets
Provide a responsive, calendar-like weekly view with navigation between weeks and clear visualization of tasks per day
Offer controls to reset/clear all data for a fresh syllabus
nonfunctional_requirements: Offline-first: the app operates entirely in the browser without a backend
Performance: generating a plan from a typical syllabus should complete within a few seconds on common devices
Accessibility: keyboard navigable, screen-reader friendly, and with adequate color contrast
Compatibility: works in modern browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Edge) on desktop and mobile, with responsive layout
Data privacy and security: no network requests or authentication; data remains in localStorage unless user exports it
Reliability: robust error handling for malformed input and clear user-facing error messages
risks: User friction during manual mapping when automatic parsing fails
LocalStorage data loss if users clear browser data or use private/incognito mode
Inaccurate syllabus-to-week mapping causing misaligned study plans
Limited MVP scope may hinder perceived usefulness or adoption
Performance or UI complexity if syllabi are very large or highly structured
open_questions: Should the MVP support multiple syllabi per user or just a single active syllabus at a time?
Would exporting the plan to JSON or ICS (calendar) format be valued in the MVP, or should this be deferred?
How should weeks start (e.g., Monday vs Sunday) and how to handle courses with irregular deadlines across weeks?
What level of automated parsing is acceptable, and how should manual mapping be facilitated to minimize effort?
Is there a need for basic localization or language support beyond English in the MVP?

data.title: Syllabus-to-Weekly Plan Planner
data.one_liner: A lightweight web app that converts course syllabi into personalized weekly study plans and tracks progress across the semester.
target_users: College students (undergraduates) seeking structured study plans
Students juggling multiple courses who need a weekly roadmap
assumptions: Syllabi are accessible in text form or can be pasted into the app
Users have a list of courses and weekly time availability to map tasks
Local storage or lightweight local database is acceptable for MVP data persistence
Users value weekly progress tracking but do not require calendar integrations in v1
success_metrics: Number of users who generate at least one weekly plan per course in a session
Average time to generate a weekly plan from a syllabus
User satisfaction rating (0-5) after first use
Retention: percentage of users who return to edit/view plans within a week
Qualitative feedback from local demos on usability and usefulness

prd.title: Syllabus-to-Weekly Plan Planner
prd.problem: Students struggle to convert course syllabi into actionable weekly study plans. They need a lightweight, MVP-grade web app that can accept syllabus text, produce per-course weekly plans aligned to their available study hours, and track progress locally without external integrations.
target_users: College students (undergraduates) seeking structured study plans
Students juggling multiple courses who need a weekly roadmap
goals: Convert syllabus text into weekly, course-specific study plans
Allow users to define weekly availability per course and generate feasible plans
Provide a simple, browsable view of weekly tasks per course across the semester
Track progress locally (task completion) and display completion metrics
Deliver a demoable MVP within 2 weeks that runs entirely in the browser
Avoid any external integrations or server dependencies in v1
Persist user data locally (in-browser) between sessions
non_goals: Advanced analytics or predictive scheduling beyond simple hour-based allocation
LMS integrations, assignment submission tracking, or grade calculations
Mobile app edition or iOS/Android-native features
user_stories: As a student, I want to paste a syllabus text for a course so the app can extract topics and create a plan scaffold.
As a student, I want to add multiple courses with names and their total weeks, so I can plan across a semester.
As a student, I want to specify my weekly study hours per course, so tasks are allocated to realistic time blocks.
As a student, I want the app to generate a week-by-week plan for each course based on topics and available hours.
As a student, I want to view a dashboard that shows weekly tasks for each course in a single glance.
As a student, I want to mark tasks as completed and see progress percentages to stay motivated.
As a student, I want to edit or reallocate tasks when my schedule changes, without losing data.
As a student, I want to export or print my current weekly plan for offline reference.
As a student, I want my data saved locally so it persists across browser sessions.
functional_requirements: Allow per-course setup: course name, number of weeks, and optional syllabus text input
Accept syllabus text input for each course and perform lightweight parsing to extract topics or modules
Provide a planning engine that assigns topics to weeks based on user-entered weekly hours and a simple rule set
Offer an editable weekly view where users can adjust tasks, estimated hours, and week assignment
Provide progress tracking: mark tasks complete, calculate completion rate per course and overall
Implement local data persistence using browser storage (localStorage or equivalent) with data schema for courses, weeks, tasks, and progress
Present an overview dashboard and per-course weekly breakdown views in a responsive UI
Support data export (JSON or printable text) and data import for restoration
Operate entirely client-side with no external network requests or integrations
nonfunctional_requirements: Performance: initial plan generation should complete within a few seconds on a modern browser
Reliability: works offline and persists data across sessions without server interaction
Usability: simple, clean UI with intuitive onboarding and minimal learning curve
Accessibility: keyboard-navigable controls and proper ARIA labels; color contrasts for readability
Compatibility: supported in major desktop browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) with responsive layout
Security/Privacy: no data leaves the user’s device; clearly communicate local storage usage
risks: Syllabus parsing accuracy: heterogeneity of syllabus formats may hinder automatic topic extraction
Scope creep: risk of adding features beyond MVP (calendar sync, LMS integration)
Performance with large syllabi or long-term plans could degrade if not optimized
User adoption: students may prefer existing tools or require a more guided experience
Data loss risk if localStorage capacity is exceeded or users clear data unintentionally
open_questions: What is the minimum viable syllabus parsing approach (manual mapping vs. auto-extraction) and how will users correct parsing errors?
How many weeks should the MVP assume by default, and how should it handle non-standard semester lengths (14 vs 15 weeks)?
What rules will the planning engine use to allocate topics to weeks (e.g., even distribution, priority-based, or time-block based)?
Should the export format include a human-readable printable view, or only machine-friendly JSON, or both?
How will the UI scale when handling 2-4 courses simultaneously, and is a per-course toggle preferred for initial MVP?
What accessibility and localization considerations should be included from the start (labels, date formats, etc.)?
